content.text: The universal asynchronous receiver-transmitter (UART) module provides an interface for serial communication
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: This interface can be used transfer data between a MSPM0 device and another device with an asynchronous
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: serial communication protocol like LIN (local interconnection network), ISO7816 (Smart card protocol), IrDA
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: (infrared data association), hardware flow control (CTS/RTS) and multiprocessor communications are supported.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The UART controller includes the following features:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Even, odd, stick, or no-parity bit generation and detection
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: LSB-first or MSB-first data transmit and receive
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Glitch filter on the input signals
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Programmable baud-rate generation with oversampling by 16, 8 or 3
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Separated transmit and receive 4 depth FIFOs reduce CPU interrupt service loading
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Active in all low-power mode including stop and standby mode
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Support for waking up SYSOSC via an asynchronous fast clock request upon start bit detection when
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: operating in low power modes (supports up to 19200B rates when using SYSOSC in FCL mode (1%
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: There are two types of UART instances: Extend and Main. The following table compares the features of UART
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: This section describes the operation of the UART peripheral.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The UART internal functional clock is selected and divided from the functional clock of the IP.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Use UARTx.CLKSEL register to select the source of the UART functional clock.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: BUSSCLK: the current bus clock is selected as the source for UART. The current bus clock depends on
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: power domain. If the UART instance is in power domain 1 (

content.text: LFCLK: LFCLK is selected as the source for UART, refer to

content.text: Use UARTx.CLKDIV register to select the divide ratio of the UART function clock,options are from divide by 1
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: to 8. For UART Extend, there is a CLKDIV2 register to further divide the UART function clock to support the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: IrDA mode. When using IrDA mode, CLKDIV2.RATIO must be set to 1h for proper IrDA clocking.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The selected source clock is always available and the frequency depends on the power mode, for more
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: section. After enabling the UART module by setting the ENABLE bit,
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the module will be ready to start receiving and transmitting data.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UART communications require two pins: Receive Data (RX) and Transmit Data (TX):
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: RX (Receive Data): RX is the serial data input. Glitch filter and oversampling techniques are used on the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: receive signal to ensure accurate incoming data.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: TX (Transmit Data): TX is the serial data output. When the transmitter is enabled and no data needs to be
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: transmitted, the TX pin will be held high. In some bidirectional protocols like ISO7816 Smart card, this pin is
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: In hardware flow control mode, the following pins are also used:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: CTS (Clear To Send): when driven high by external signal, this signal blocks the data transmission at the end
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: RTS (Request To Send): when low, this signal indicates that the UART is ready to receive data.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UART transmits and receives characters at a bit rate that is asynchronous to another device. Timing for each
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: character is based on the selected baud-rate. The transmit and receive functions use the same baud-rate
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: In general, control registers should only be programmed when the UART is disabled (ENABLE bit in the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UARTx.CTL0 register is cleared). If the UART is operating and gets disabled during transmit or receive
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: operation, the current transaction gets completed before the UART stops. The baud-rate divisor registers
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: (UARTx.IBRD and UARTx.FBRD) can be modified without disabling the UART.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The transmit logic performs parallel-to-serial conversion on the data read from the transmit FIFO. The control
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: logic outputs the serial bit stream beginning with a start bit and followed by the data bits (LSB first), parity bit,
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: and the stop bits according to the programmed configuration.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The receive logic performs serial-to-parallel conversion on the received bit stream after a valid start pulse has
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: been detected. Overrun, parity, frame error checking, and line-break detection are also performed, and their
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: status accompanies the data that is written to the receive FIFO, this is the reason for 12-bit receive FIFO.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UARTx.CTL0.ENABLE bit is used to enable and disable the UART module, UARTx.CTL0.TXE and RXE bits are
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: used to enable the transmit and receive mode, UARTx.LCRH.WLEN bit is used to configure the number of data
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: bits transmitted or received in a frame, UARTx.LCRH.PEN is used to enable parity and UARTx.LCRH.STP2 is
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: used to send two stop bits.
content.label: TABLE_ROW

content.text: By default, UARTx.CTL0.HSE is set to 0 and 16 oversampling is selected and receiving bits are expected to
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: have the length of 16 UART clock UARTclk cycles and is sampled on the 8th UARTclk cycle.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Setting the UARTx.CTL0.HSE bit to 1 selects the 8 oversampling where the receiving bits are expected to have
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the length of 8 UART clock UARTclk cycles and is sampled on the 4th UARTclk cycle.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Setting the UARTx.CTL0.HSE bit to 2 selects the 3 oversampling, the receiving bits are expected to have the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: length of 3 UART clock UARTclk cycles and are sampled on the 2nd UARTclk cycle.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The aforementioned scenarios assume an IBRD =1 and FBRD =0.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Select oversampling by 3 or 8 to achieve higher speed with UARTclk/8 or UARTclk/3. In this case the receiver
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: tolerance to clock deviation is reduced.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Select oversampling by 16 to increase the tolerance of the receiver to clock deviations. The maximum speed
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The majority voting feature of the UART provides noise immunity by sampling each bit 3 times in the center
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: of the bit period. For example, in the case when the UARTx.CTL0.HSE is set to 0 with 16 oversampling; the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: 7th, 8th and 9th bit are sampled and the majority value is considered as final value to be sampled. When the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UARTx.CTL0.HSE is set to 1 with 8 oversampling; then the 3rd ,4th and 5th bits are sampled and majority value
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: is considered as final value to be sampled. The oversampling is only applicable for 16 and 8 oversampling.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: When the 3 samples used for majority vote are not equal; the RIS.NE (noise error bit) is set. The received data
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: is transferred despite the noise error. The NE bit will get appended to the received data before storing it in the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: RXDATA register at bit position 12. Please note that the majority voting feature is implemented only for data bits.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: One can select majority voting or single sample using the MAJVOTE control bit in the CTL0 register.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Even though UART instances have noise filters, this feature provides an extra layer of noise immunity
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The baud-rate divisor is a 22-bit number consisting of a 16-bit integer and a 6-bit fractional part. The number
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: formed by these two values is used by the baud-rate generator to determine the bit sample period. Having a
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: fractional baud-rate divisor allows the UART to generate all of the standard baud-rates very accurately
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The 16-bit integer is loaded through the UART Integer Baud-Rate Divisor UARTx.IBRD register and the 6-bit
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: fractional part is loaded with the UART Fractional Baud-Rate Divisor UARTx.FBRD register.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The baud-rate divisor can be calculated by using the following formula:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: BRD = UART Clock / (Oversampling x Baud rate)
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UART clock is the clock output of the UART clock control logic, configured by CLKSEL and CLKDIV.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Oversampling is selected by the HSE bit in the UARTx.CTL0 register and it can be 16, 8 or 3.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UARTx.IBRD = INT(BRD), integer part of the BRD
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The integer part of BRD is loaded into UARTx.IBRD register. The 6-bit fractional number must be loaded into the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: When IBRD = 0, FBRD is ignored and no data gets transferred by the UART. Similarly, when IBRD =
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: 65535 (that is 0xFFFF), then FBRD must not be greater than zero. If this is exceeded it results in an
content.label: BULLET_POINT

content.text: The following example shows a simple method to calculate IBRD.DIVINT and FBRD.DIVFRAC for a baud rate of
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Note: The adder ‘+0.5’ ensures rounding to the closest integer value to
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: keep the rounding error as small as possible
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: When updating the baud-rate divisor (UARTx.IBRD or UARTx.IFRD), the UART.LCRH register must also be
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: written, so any changes to the baud-rate divisor must be followed by a write to the LCRH register for the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: changes to take effect. The contents of the UART.IBRD and UART.FBRD registers are not updated until
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: transmission or reception of the current character is complete.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Data received or transmitted is stored in two FIFOs, though the receive FIFO has an extra four bits per character
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: For transmission, data is written into the transmit FIFO. If the UART is enabled, it causes a data frame to start
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: transmitting with the parameters indicated in the UARTx.LCRH register. Data continues to be transmitted until
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: there is no data left in the transmit FIFO. The BUSY bit in the UARTx.STAT register is asserted as soon as
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: data is written to the transmit FIFO (that is, if the FIFO is nonempty) and remains asserted while data is being
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: transmitted. The BUSY bit is negated only when the transmit FIFO is empty, and the last character has been
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: transmitted to the shift register, including the stop bits. The UART can indicate that it is busy even though the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UART can no longer be enabled. BUSY also is set during the generation of a BREAK signal.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: When the receiver is idle (the RX signal is continuously 1), and the data input goes low (a start bit has
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: been received), the receive counter begins running and data is sampled on the different cycle based on the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: oversampling setting of the HSE bit in UARTx.CTL0 register .The start bit is valid and recognized if the RX
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: signal is still low after certain number for cycles based on the oversampling setting. After a valid start bit is
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: detected, successive data bits are sampled according to the programmed length of the data characters. The
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: parity bit is then checked if parity mode is enabled. Data length and parity are defined in the UART.LCRH
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Lastly, a valid stop bit is confirmed if the RXD signal is high, otherwise a framing error has occurred. When a full
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: word is received, the data is stored in the receive FIFO along with any error bits associated with that word.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: For received data, the data byte and the 4-bit status (break, frame, parity, and overrun) is pushed onto the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: 12-bit wide receive FIFO. The error and status can be can be retrieved by reading UARTx.RXDATA register as
content.label: BULLET_POINT

content.text: A framing error occurs when a low stop bit is detected. When two stop bits are used, both
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: stop bits are checked for framing error. When a framing error is detected, the FRMERR bit
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: A parity error is a mismatch between the number of 1s in a character and the value of
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the parity bit. When an address bit is included in the character, it is included in the parity
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: calculation. When a parity error is detected, the PARERR bit is set.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: An overrun error occurs when a character is loaded into RXDATA/FIFO before the prior
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: character has been read. When an overrun occurs, the OVRERR bit is set.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: A break is detected when all received data, parity, and stop bits are 0. When a break
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: condition is detected, the BRKERR bit is set. A break condition can also set the interrupt
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: flag RXINT if the break interrupt enable IMASK.BRKERR bit is set.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Framing error and break condition are not set when LIN mode is enabled, this pattern is used to signal a Sync frame for LIN. Break
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: detection is not available for IRDA, Manchester and Dali mode.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: This bit is set as soon as the transmit FIFO becomes nonempty (regardless of whether UART is enabled). In
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: IDLE_Line mode the busy signal also stays set during the idle time generation.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: This bit is set when receive FIFO is empty. If the FIFO is disabled (FEN is 0), the receive holding register is full. If
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the FIFO is enabled (FEN is 1), the receive FIFO is full.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: This bit is set when receive FIFO is full. If the FIFO is disabled (FEN is 0), the receive holding register is empty. If
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the FIFO is enabled (FEN is 1), the receive FIFO is empty.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: This bit is set when transmit FIFO is empty. If the FIFO is disabled (FEN is 0), the transmit holding register is full.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If the FIFO is enabled (FEN is 1), the transmit FIFO is full.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: This bit is set when transmit FIFO is full. If the FIFO is disabled (FEN is 0), the transmit holding register is empty.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If the FIFO is enabled (FEN is 1), the transmit FIFO is empty.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: This bit is set when CTS signal is asserted (low) and cleared when CTS signal is not asserted (high).
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: IDLE mode has been detected in idle line multiprocessor mode. The IDLE bit is used as an address tag for each
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: block of characters. In idle line multiprocessor format, this bit is set when a received character is an address.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: This section is only relevant for UART Extend, which supports LIN mode. Refer to the device data sheet for the

content.text: For supporting local interconnect network (LIN) protocol, the following hardware enhancements are implemented

content.text: 16 bit up-counter (LINCNT) clocked by the UART clock.

content.label: BULLET_POINT

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Compare of LINCNT with interrupt capability on match.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: BULLET_POINT

content.text: Capture LINCNT value on RXD rising edge. Interrupt capability on capture.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Sending the break signal can be done by setting the BRK bit in UARTx.LCRH register. This bit needs to be set
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: before the data is written into the FIFO or transmit data register TXDATA.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: To generate LIN responder signals such as wake signals, the TX pin can be configured by TXD_OUT and
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: TXD_CTL_EN bits in register UARTx.CTL0 to be software controlled. By setting TXD_CTL_EN bit to 1, the TX
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: output pin can be controlled by the TXD_OUT bit if the UART transmit is disabled (CTL0.TXE is cleared).
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The interrupt RXINT for starting the transmission on the responder line always occurs at the mid-point of the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: commander STOP bit. Depending on the BUSCLK and baud-rate; there might not be enough response space
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Flow control can be accomplished by hardware and the following sections describe the implementation method.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: In UART mode (CTL0.MODE set to 0), hardware flow control between two devices is accomplished by
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: connecting the RTS output to the CTS input on the receiving device, and connecting the RTS output on the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: receiving device to the CTS input. The RTS output signal is low active, the CTS input expects a low signal on a
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The CTS input controls the transmitter, the Device 0 and Device 1 transmitter can only transmit data when
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: their CTS input is asserted low. When RTS flow control is enabled, the RTS output signal indicates the state
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: of the receive FIFO. For example, the CTS of the Device 1 remains asserted low until the preprogrammed RX
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: FIFO level of Device 0 is reached, indicating that the receive FIFO of Device 0 has no space to store additional
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The CTSEN and RTSEN bits in the UART.CTL0 register specify the flow control mode as shown in
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: RTS and CTS flow control enabled
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Both RTS and CTS flow control disabled
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: When RTSEN is set to 1, the value of the CTL0.RTS bit is ignored and the RTS output signal is generated by the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: hardware trigger levels as described below. When RTSEN bit is cleared, the RTS signal output is controlled by
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the CTL0.RTS bit for SW control.
content.label: TABLE_ROW

content.text: The RTS flow control logic is linked to the programmable receive FIFO watermark levels, it can be configured
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: using UARTx.IFLS register. When RTS flow control is enabled, the RTS is asserted (low) until the receive
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: FIFO is filled up to the watermark level. When the receive FIFO watermark level is reached, the RTS signal is
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: de-asserted (high), indicating that there is no more room to receive any more data. The transmission of data is
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: expected to cease after the current character has been transmitted. The RTS signal is reasserted (low) when
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: data has been read out of the receive FIFO so that it is filled to less than the watermark level. If RTS flow control
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: is disabled and the UART is still enabled, then data is received until the receive FIFO is full, or no more data is
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: As the RTS signal is de-asserted when the FIFO watermark level is reached by putting the last received
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: character into the FIFO. This means on a back to back transmit another character transfer could already been
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: started by the sender. Therefore, in such cases the watermark level should be set to one level lower to ensure all
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: data can be received and put into the FIFO.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If CTS flow control is enabled, then the transmitter checks the CTS signal before transmitting the next byte. If
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the CTS signal is asserted (low), it transmits the byte otherwise transmission does not occur. The data continues
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: to be transmitted while CTS is asserted (low), and the transmit FIFO is not empty. If the transmit FIFO is empty
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: and the CTS signal is asserted (low) no data is transmitted. If the CTS signal is de-asserted (high) and CTS flow
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: control is enabled, then the current character transmission is completed before stopping. If CTS flow control is
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: disabled and the UART is enabled, then the data continues to be transmitted until the transmit FIFO is empty.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: When IDLELINE is set in the CTL0.MODE register bits, the idle-line multiprocessor format is selected. Blocks
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: of data are separated by an idle time on the transmit or receive lines (
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: detected when ten or more continuous ones (marks) are received after the one or two stop bits of a character.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The baud-rate generator is switched off after reception of an idle line until the next start edge is detected. When
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: an idle line is detected, the IDLE bit in UARTx.STAT is set. In Idle-Line mode the UART receiver operates in no
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: parity mode and the UART word length (UARTx.LCRH.WLEN) must be set to 8bit.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: which follows an idle period of 10
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The first character received after an idle period is an address character. The IDLE bit in UARTx.STAT register
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: is used as an address tag for each block of characters. In idle-line multiprocessor format, this bit is set when a
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If an address character is received it is compared against the ADDR register with the AMASK applied. If the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: received character matches, the address character and all following received characters are transferred into the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: RXDATA buffer and interrupts/flags are generated until the next address without a match is received. The IDLE
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: bit in UARTx.STAT register is automatically cleared when the address does match; otherwise the IDLE bit is set
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: When the SENDIDLE bit in UARTx.LCRH register is set the UART inserts an idle period of 11 bit times on the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: bus, an ongoing transfer is finished first. The next transfer will be delayed till this idle period has finished. Then
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the next transfer can start with an address character.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The following procedure sends out an idle frame to indicate an address character followed by associated data:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Set SENDIDLE then write the address character to TXDATA. TXDATA must be ready for new data (TXINT
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: interrupt must be 1). This generates an idle period of exactly 11 bits followed by the address character.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: SENDIDLE is reset automatically when the address character has been transferred (all bits are sent out of
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Write desired data characters to TXDATA. TXDATA must be ready for new data (TXINT interrupt must be 1).
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The data written to TXDATA is transferred to the shift register and transmitted as soon as the shift register is
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The idle-line time must not be exceeded between address and data transmission or between data transmissions.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Otherwise, the transmitted data is misinterpreted as an address.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: TX: BUSY is set during the generation of an IDLELINE signal and while the address and data bytes are sent
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: RX: The BUSY signal set during the receive of data and till first 10 idle bits are received.

content.text: 9-bit mode is enabled by setting MODE bit to ADDR9BIT in the UARTx.CTL0 register. This feature is useful
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: in a multi-drop configuration of the UART where a single controller connected to multiple peripherals can
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: communicate with a particular peripheral through its address or set of addresses along with a qualifier for
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: an address byte. In 9-bit UART mode, the parity enable/mode bits are ignored and the UART word length
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: In 9-bit mode, a peripheral checks for the address qualifier at the location of the parity bit. If set, the received
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: byte is compared with the preprogrammed address in UARTx.ADDR register:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If the address matches, a 9-bit mode address match interrupt (ADDR_MATCH) is generated, if enabled and
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If the address does not match, the address byte and the subsequent data bytes get dropped. .
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The address can be predefined in the UART.ADDR register to match with the received byte. The matching
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: can be extended to a set of addresses using the address mask in the UART.AMASK register. By default, the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UART.AMASK is 0xFF, meaning that only the specified address must match
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: All the send transactions in 9-bit UART mode are interpreted as:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Address bytes, if the 9th bit is set
content.label: TABLE_ROW

content.text: Data bytes, if the 9th bit is cleared
content.label: TABLE_ROW

content.text: In 9-bit mode, the 9th bit can be controlled by software. The EPS bit setting of the LCRH register reflects the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: 9th bit for transmit transactions. To indicate an address byte, the software must set the EPS bit before the byte
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: transmission. For data byte transmissions, the EPS bit must be cleared before the byte transmission. For a
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: complete transmit transaction, the address byte must be transmitted as a single byte transaction with EPS bit
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: set, followed by a data byte burst with EPS bit cleared.

content.text: RS485 is a standard used in serial communications systems. This standard can be used effectively over long
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: distances and in electrically noisy environments. Multiple receivers can be connected to such a network. These
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: characteristics make RS-485 useful in industrial control systems and similar applications.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: DALI stands for Digital Addressable Lighting Interface. It is an International Standard (IEC 62386) lighting control
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: system, providing a single interface for all electronic control gear (light sources) and electronic control devices
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The UART module supports the low level DALI Protocol sending and receiving the bit streams for forward and
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: backward frames. The timing between any forward and backward frame sequence needs to be handled and
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Transmitting a forward or backward frame:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: When transmitting a forward frame user needs to ensure to write second byte to buffer before first byte has been
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: shifted out. The hardware will then send the two bytes without inserting the stop bits in-between. Otherwise the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: stop bits will be sent and the data will be handled like a backward frame.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The UART module in DALI mode will check the 9th bit after the start bit to detect a Forward frame or backward
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: frame. If this bit does have a change of the phase (= no stop bit) a forward frame is detected and:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Address compare is done in software or hardware depending on MASK
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Address and data are always transferred into the RX Buffer
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Otherwise a backward frame is detected and the data is transferred into the RX Buffer without setting the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The limits for the times T shall be: 334 µs < T < 500 µs according to standard IEC 62386-102. DALI mode
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UART provides option to receive and transmit Manchester encoded data. The function is enabled by the MENC
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The output signal is generated by XORing the data with UART clock signal. The UART clock needs to be double
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the speed of the baud-rate. So for the data transmit there is an edge at the beginning and the middle of each
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: data bit. For the receive signal the edge in the middle of the bit is detected to decode the RX data.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: When IREN bit in UARTx.IRCTL register is set, the IrDA encoder and decoder are enabled and provide
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: hardware bit shaping for IrDA communication. IrDA en/decoding should only be used with UART mode
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The encoder sends a pulse for every zero bit in the transmit bit stream coming from the UART (see
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: ). The pulse duration is defined by IRTXPL bits specifying the number of one-half clock periods of the clock
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: (more information will be added in next revision)
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The decoder detects high pulses when IRRXPL = 0. Otherwise, it detects low pulses.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: A programmable digital filter stage can be enabled by setting UARTx.GFCTL.DGFSEL > 0. When IRCTL.IREN
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: is set, also the digital glitch filter should be set so that only pulses longer than the programmed filter length are
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: passed and shorter pulses are discarded. (See the Glitch Suppression chapter on how to set the filter.)
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If a parity error is detected during a transmission, RXD is pulled low during the second stop bit. In this case,
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the UART aborts the transmission, it flushes the transmit FIFO and discards any data it contains. Additionally
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: it raises a parity error interrupt, allowing the software to detect the problem and initiate retransmission of
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the affected data, as the UART does not support automatic retransmission in this case. The UART does not
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: support automatic retransmission on parity errors. If a parity error is detected on transmission, all further transmit
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: operations are aborted and software must handle retransmission of the affected byte or message.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: In Smartcard Mode, the receiver in case of parity error will drive the line low and a parity interrupt flag is
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: asserted. The transmitter responds based on the value of this bit.

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The UART has two FIFOs with a depth of 4 entries, one for transmit and one for receive. The FIFOs are
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: accessed through the UART Data (TXDATA/RXDATA) registers. Read operations of the RXDATA register return
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: a 12-bit value consisting of 8 data bits and 4 error flags. Write operations to TXDATA place 8-bit data in the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Out of reset, both FIFOs are disabled and act as 1-byte-deep holding registers. The FIFOs are enabled by
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: setting the FEN bit in UARTx.CTL0. FIFO status can be monitored through the UARTx.STAT register and the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Hardware monitors empty, full and overrun conditions
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The UARTx.STAT register contains empty and full flags (TXFE, TXFF, RXFE, and RXFF bits), and the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: CPU_INT.RIS register shows overrun status of the receive FIFO through the OVRERR bit. There is no indicator
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: for a transmit FIFO overrun. A write is just lost, in case it overruns the transmit FIFO. If the FIFOs are disabled,
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the empty and full flags are set according to the status of the 1-byte-deep holding registers. When receiving
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: more data than the FIFO can capture the oldest data will be overwritten with the received data.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The trigger point at which the FIFOs generate interrupts is controlled through the UARTx.IFLS register. Both
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: FIFOs can be individually configured to trigger interrupts at different levels. Available configurations for transmit
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: FIFO include 3/4, 1/2, 1/4 and empty, for receive FIFO 1/4, 1/2, 3/4 and full. For example, if the 3/4 option is
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: selected for the receive FIFO, the UART generates a receive interrupt after 3 data bytes are received. Out of
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: reset, both FIFOs are configured to trigger an interrupt at the 1/2 mark. The FIFO integrity is indeterminate under
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The UART can be placed into an internal loopback mode for diagnostic or debug work by setting the LBE bit in
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the UART.CTL0 register. In loopback mode, the UART operates with the following behavior:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Data transmitted on the TX output is received on the RX input
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Data transmitted on the TX output is not propagated to the TX IO pin
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Data received on the RX IO pin is ignored
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: Digital filter is based on the UART functional clock. The DGFSEL bits in the UARTx.GFCTL register can
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: be programmed to provide glitch suppression on the RX line and assure proper signal values. The glitch
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: suppression value is in terms of functional clocks. All signals are delayed internally when glitch suppression is
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: nonzero. For example, if DGFSEL is set to 0x5, 5 clocks should be added onto the calculation for the expected
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: transaction time. The DGFSEL need to be configured for the glitch suppression pulse width to be shorter than
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: 1/3 of a normal data pulse, to avoid a normal pulse is filtered unexpectedly.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The analog glitch suppression on the RX line is based on the analog glitch filter and it can be selected with the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: AGFSEL bits in the UARTx.GFCTL register. See data sheet for the select-able glitch filter values. The analog
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: glitch filter is enabled with the AGFEN, if not set the input signals will be passed through to the UART module
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The receive timeout interrupt is asserted when the receive FIFO is not empty, and no further data is received
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: specified time in the IFLS.RXTOSEL bits. The receive timeout interrupt is cleared either when the FIFO becomes
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: empty through reading all the data (or by reading the holding register), by reading the interrupt index from IIDX
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: or when a 1 is written to the corresponding bit in the ICLR register.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The receive interrupt (RXINT, 0x0B) changes state when one of the following events occurs:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If the FIFOs are enabled and the receive FIFO reaches the programmed trigger level, the RXINT bit is set.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The receive interrupt is cleared by reading data from the receive FIFO until it becomes less than the trigger
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: level, by reading the interrupt index from IIDX or by writing a 1 to the RXINT bit in ICLR.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If the FIFOs are disabled (have a depth of one location) and data is received thereby filling the location, the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: RXINT bit is set. The receive interrupt is cleared by performing a single read of the receive FIFO, by reading
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the interrupt index from IIDX or by writing a 1 to the RXINT bit in ICLR.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The transmit interrupt (TXINT, 0x0C) changes state when one of the following events occurs:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If the FIFOs are enabled and the transmit FIFO progresses through the programmed trigger level, the TXINT
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: bit is set. The transmit interrupt is based on a transition through level, therefore the FIFO must be written past
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the programmed trigger level otherwise no further transmit interrupts will be generated. The transmit interrupt
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: is cleared by writing data to the transmit FIFO until it becomes greater than the trigger level, by reading the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: interrupt index from IIDX or by writing a 1 to the TXINT bit in ICLR.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If the FIFOs are disabled (have a depth of one location) and there is no data present in the transmitters single

content.text: The receive interrupt (RXINT, 0x0B) changes state when one of the following events occurs:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If the FIFOs are enabled and the receive FIFO reaches the programmed trigger level, the RXINT bit is set.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The receive interrupt is cleared by reading data from the receive FIFO until it becomes less than the trigger
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: level, by reading the interrupt index from IIDX or by writing a 1 to the RXINT bit in ICLR.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If the FIFOs are disabled (have a depth of one location) and data is received thereby filling the location, the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: RXINT bit is set. The receive interrupt is cleared by performing a single read of the receive FIFO, by reading
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the interrupt index from IIDX or by writing a 1 to the RXINT bit in ICLR.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UART transmit interrupt. More information provided below.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The transmit interrupt (TXINT, 0x0C) changes state when one of the following events occurs:
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If the FIFOs are enabled and the transmit FIFO progresses through the programmed trigger level, the TXINT
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: bit is set. The transmit interrupt is based on a transition through level, therefore the FIFO must be written past
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the programmed trigger level otherwise no further transmit interrupts will be generated. The transmit interrupt
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: is cleared by writing data to the transmit FIFO until it becomes greater than the trigger level, by reading the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: interrupt index from IIDX or by writing a 1 to the TXINT bit in ICLR.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: If the FIFOs are disabled (have a depth of one location) and there is no data present in the transmitters single
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: location, the TXINT bit is set. It is cleared by performing a single write to the transmit FIFO, by reading the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: interrupt index from IIDX or by writing a 1 to the TXINT bit in ICLR.

content.text: This register provides the highest priority enabled interrupt index. Value 0x00 means no event pending. Interrupt
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: set to 1 denotes the highest priority pending interrupt. The priority order is fixed. However, users can implement
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: their own prioritization schemes using other registers that expose the full set of interrupts that have occurred.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The Stick Parity Select (SPS) bit is used to set either a permanent '1'
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: or a permanent '0' as parity when transmitting or receiving data. Its
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: purpose is to typically indicate the first byte of a package or to mark
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: an address byte, for example in a multi-drop RS-485 network.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: When bits PEN, EPS, and SPS of UARTLCRH are set, the parity bit
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: is transmitted and checked as a 0.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: The IFLS register is the interrupt FIFO level select register. You can use this register to define the levels at which
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the TX, RX and timeout interrupt flags are triggered. The interrupts are generated based on a transition through
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: a level rather than being based on the level. That is, the interrupts are generated when the fill level progresses
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: through the trigger level. For example, if the receive trigger level is set to the half-way mark, the interrupt is
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: triggered when the receive FIFO is filled with two or more characters. Out of reset, the TXIFLSEL and RXIFLSEL
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: bits are configured so that the FIFOs trigger an interrupt at the half-way mark.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UART Transmit Data Register. This register is the transmit data register (the interface to the FIFOs). For
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: transmitted data, if the FIFO is enabled, data written to this location is pushed onto the transmit FIFO. If the FIFO
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: is disabled, data is stored in the transmitter holding register (the bottom word of the transmit FIFO). A write to
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: this register initiates a transmission from the UART.
content.label: TABLE_ROW

content.text: Data Transmitted or Received Data that is to be transmitted via the
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UART is written to this field. When read, this field contains the data
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: that was received by the UART.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UART Receive Data Register. This register is the data receive register (the interface to the FIFOs). For received
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: data, if the FIFO is enabled, the data byte and the 4-bit status (break, frame, parity, and overrun) is pushed onto
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: the 12-bit wide receive FIFO. If the FIFO is disabled, the data byte and status are stored in the receiving holding
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: register (the bottom word of the receive FIFO). The received data can be retrieved by reading this register.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: UART Receive Overrun Error Writing to this bit has no effect. The
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: flag is cleared by writing 1 to the OVRERR bit in the UART EVENT
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: ICLR register. In case of a receive FIFO overflow, the FIFO contents
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: remain valid because no further data is written when the FIFO is full.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.text: read the data to empty the FIFO.
content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH

content.label: PARAGRAPH
